description: A plank with a handle and a whittled-down point.  Not much good for slashing, but much better than your bare hands.
A plank with a handle and a whittled-down point, left large enough to require two hands.  Still not much good for slashing, but far better than the plank on its own.
A nail sword, or nord for short.  This wooden sword has a dozen nails sticking out at jagged angles from the edge of the blade, making it much better at chopping than slashing.
Several bits of thin scrap metal crudely beat into the semblance of an edge over a wooden sword.  The added weight is unbalanced, but the jagged edge offers a good bit of slashing power.
A large wooden sword with scrap metal hammered over it into something pretending to be an edge.  The extra weight almost completely front-loads the balance, and it hurts your wrists just to wield.
A vicious single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered twice over itself then welded together.  It's not as robust as a proper forged sword, but the edge is wickedly sharp.

variants.description: A vicious single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered twice over itself then welded together.  It's not as robust as a proper forged sword, but the edge is wickedly sharp.

A vicious single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered twice over itself then bolted together.  It's not quite a katana made from steel folded a thousand times over, but it has a certain industrial charm to it.

description: A long-handled single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered thrice over itself then welded together.  The extra length and weight makes it a tad awkward, but gives it a lot of slashing power.

variants.description: A long-handled single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered thrice over itself then welded together.  The extra length and weight makes it a tad awkward, but gives it a lot of slashing power.
A long-handled single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered thrice over itself then bolted together.  It vaguely resembles a Japanese nagamaki if you squint.

description: An imitation of a true sword forged by someone who knows what swords look like, at least.  Made from whatever scrap metal was on hand, it has the general shape of a sword, and it is sharp, but it is a bit heavier than it should be and the balance isn't quite right.
A large, crudely-forged blade.  It's too big to be called a sword.  Too massive, too thick, too heavy, and far too rough.
//: It's not razor-sharp and most of the damage is coming from the heavy weight, hence the high bash-to-cut ratio.

description: Calling this a rapier is a stretch.  It's robust and very pointy, but more akin to a long metal spike with a handguard than the elegant swords of the Renaissance.
A long, thin knife with a spring-loaded blade that rests inside the handle while not in use.

variants.description: A flashy knife with hinged handles that completely conceal the blade while folded.  Popular among movie gangbangers and people who thought fidget spinners were too safe.
A long, thin knife with a spring-loaded blade that rests inside the handle while not in use.

description: A small folding knife with a locking blade and a pocket clip.  Not as good a weapon as a solid fixed-blade knife, but better than a penknife.

A modern bayonet in use with the US Marine Corps, adopted in an effort to improve USMC hand-to-hand fighting capabilities.  The bayonet is optimized to function as a fighting knife, sporting an ergonomic handle that will minimize hand fatigue during combat.  The blade tip is sharper in profile than other bayonets to assist in penetrating body armor, and also features a small serrated section to provide for some utility.

The current issue Army bayonet, before the Cataclysm anyways.  It is thick, heavy, and surprisingly sharp.  This bayonet also functions as a wire cutter, and a mediocre saw for cutting through aircraft fuselage.  That the handle and tang can be completely disassembled from the blade is surely a fact of great comfort to the soldier, survivalist, and you.

variants.description: The current issue Army bayonet, before the Cataclysm anyways.  It is thick, heavy, and surprisingly sharp.  This bayonet also functions as a wire cutter, and a mediocre saw for cutting through aircraft fuselage.  That the handle and tang can be completely disassembled from the blade is surely a fact of great comfort to the soldier, survivalist, and you.

A 6H4 bayonet for Kalashnikov pattern rifles, usually imported military surplus from eastern bloc countries.  The blade is made of stainless steel and the handle of a lightweight and durable plastic.  It features a middling metal saw on the spine of the blade, and can function as a wire cutter as well.  Though it is quite sturdy, it can't hold an edge very well.

description: A Cold War era Army bayonet that has only partially been replaced by newer models.  It has an apocalypse-proof full-tang, double-edged high steel blade terminating in a spear point.  The no-frills design makes for both a good fighting knife and bayonet, a fact that was appreciated when reserve stocks of these were issued out to National Guardsmen.
//: An M4, M5, M6, or M7 Bayonet.
Highest non-powertool butchering quality.  It's made for skinning and butchering game, which is what you're generally doing.  Based on Buck 103 skinner.
description: Commonly used by hunters, this single-edged sheath knife is designed for cutting and skinning game rather than combat.

The KA-BAR was developed by the United States Marine Corps in 1942 by modifying hunting knife designs to be more soldier-proof.  The handle is made of stacked leather washers, and the blade is made of easy to sharpen high steel, making for a popular fighting, hunting and utility knife.  The blade is marked 'USMC'.
This massive knife features a hollow handle with a compass built into the pommel and a row of fearsome-looking saw teeth along the back of its blade.

This massive knife features a hollow handle with a compass built into the pommel and a row of fearsome-looking saw teeth along the back of its blade.  It's custom-made of mild steel, you could probably find better in a hunting store.

//: This isn't really supposed to be a very good knife, or a very good saw.  It's more for looking scary.
description: This massive knife features a hollow handle with a compass built into the pommel and a row of fearsome-looking saw teeth along the back of its blade.  Made of medium steel, this is about as good as store bought.

pocket_data.description: A hidden handle compartment.  Unscrew the compass to access.

description: This massive knife features a hollow handle with a compass built into the pommel and a row of fearsome-looking saw teeth along the back of its blade.  A competent weapon and tool, if not the best at any of them.
This massive knife features a hollow handle with a compass built into the pommel and a row of fearsome-looking saw teeth along the back of its blade.  Now this, this is a knife.
This massive knife features a hollow handle with a compass built into the pommel and a row of fearsome-looking saw teeth along the back of its blade.  Time to go Rambo on this apocalypse.

Arguably the most famous combat knife in military history, this blackened double-edged knife is made of drop-forged steel and knurled brass.  The balance of the knife is such that it can be tossed from one hand to the other instinctively, and the spear point allows for easy insertion into an unsuspecting foe's heart.  While this knife is great in a fight, it's not very good as a tool.  The ricasso declares this to be a 'Fairbairn-Sykes knife', with a National Stocking Number of '1095-99-963-2037'.

//: The swiss army knife is a bit more of a knife than a toolkit.
description: An iconic pocket knife imported from Europe.  Its red plastic handle conceals many small tools.
This stout combat knife features a steel guard to protect the user's knuckles.  The guard can also be used for striking or blocking.
This stout combat knife features a steel guard to protect the user's knuckles.  The guard can also be used for striking or blocking.  This one is poorly made of mild steel with barely a proper grip.
This stout combat knife features a steel guard to protect the user's knuckles.  The guard can also be used for striking or blocking.  This one is made of medium steel and is about shop quality.

This stout combat knife features a steel guard to protect the user's knuckles.  The guard can also be used for striking or blocking.  This one is made of high steel and is probably as good as a WWI trench knife.

This stout combat knife features a steel guard to protect the user's knuckles.  The guard can also be used for striking or blocking.  This one is made of hardened steel, an officer's weapon if ever there was one.

This stout combat knife features a steel guard to protect the user's knuckles.  The guard can also be used for striking or blocking.  This one is made of tempered steel, and you feel you could hold a trench against an army of zombies with it.
A knife consisting of a long, somewhat sharpened spike and a tightly-wrapped rag as a handle.  Not as good as a real knife, but it'll do in a pinch.
A femur or other bone, about 20 cm long, which has been broken at one end and sharpened into a cutting tool.  Its jagged edge is wicked but fragile.
A medieval dagger forged from rough iron.  It is not the sharpest tool in the shed, but it is certainly one of the largest.
A large blade with one end wrapped in duct tape to make a crude handle, making it easier to wield as a rough machete.
This huge steel knife makes an excellent tool for cutting down large vegetation or other 'obstacles.'
This common gardening tool has been customized and rebalanced to improve its performance as a weapon.
This common gardening tool has been customized, rebalanced and tempered to dramatically improve its performance as a weapon.

variants.description: This common gardening tool has been customized, rebalanced and tempered to dramatically improve its performance as a weapon.
This black tempered steel bushcraft machete has been reinforced for use in exotic environments.  "HE Blade" is engraved in the steel.

description: A thin, wobbly steel blade with sawteeth on one side and a flat chisel tip for digging.  More of a jackass of all trades than a jack of them.
A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onward.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onwards.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

Made with mild steel and lacking a proper grip, this is better than the sticks you swung around as a kid, but you know you can do better.

A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onwards.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

Made with medium steel and with a grip made of leather wrapped in steel wire, this weapon is comfortable in your hand, though the balance isn't perfect and the edge could be sharper.

A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onwards.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

Made with high steel and featuring a sturdy grip, this feels like a proper weapon.  The balance feels right and the blade is quite sharp.

A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onwards.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

Made of hardened steel and with a molded grip that fits your hand perfectly, this weapon looks as good as any you might find in a museum.  The balance is perfect and the edge is as sharp as a razor.

A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onwards.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

Made of tempered steel, this is a masterpiece.  The grip, the balance, the blade, all perfect.  This is the peak of the swordsmith's craft.
A dull, cheaply-made replica of a curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onwards.
This wavy-bladed dagger is from Southeast Asia.  The design of the blade causes it to make broad, painful wounds.
//: Should be split into a preexisting iron version and a craftable steel version

description: A dull, cheap replica of a wavy-bladed dagger from Southeast Asia.
This versatile implement is a modern take on a traditional weapon that originated in Nepal.  Featuring a heavy blade with an inwardly-curved edge, it can be used as both a tool and a weapon.

This versatile implement is a custom-forged version of a traditional weapon that originated in Nepal.  Featuring a heavy blade with an inwardly-curved edge, this one is made of mild steel, and barely has a proper handle.  You'd probably find a better version in a store somewhere.

This versatile implement is a custom-forged version of a traditional weapon that originated in Nepal.  Featuring a heavy blade with an inwardly-curved edge, this one is made of medium steel, and is about what you'd expect to see in a hunting shop.

This versatile implement is a custom-forged version of a traditional weapon that originated in Nepal.  Featuring a heavy blade with an inwardly-curved edge, this one is made of high steel and is a well-made piece.

This versatile implement is a custom-forged version of a traditional weapon that originated in Nepal.  Featuring a heavy blade with an inwardly-curved edge, this one is made of hardened steel and is a fine tool and weapon.

This versatile implement is a custom-forged version of a traditional weapon that originated in Nepal.  Featuring a heavy blade with an inwardly-curved edge, this one is made of tempered steel and truly a weapon worthy of a post apocalyptic gurkha.

An ancient Chinese doubled-edged straight sword, with an ornate guard and a tassel attached to the pommel.  One of the four major weapons in folklore, alongside the dao sabre, qiang spear, and gun staff.

An ancient Chinese doubled-edged straight sword, with an ornate guard and a tassel attached to the pommel.  One of the four major weapons in folklore, alongside the dao sabre, qiang spear, and gun staff.

A classic medieval sword, in between the lighter arming sword and later two-handed swords in size.  It's well-balanced and surprisingly easy to use due to its two-handed grip, but requires a larger baldric or scabbard compared to smaller swords.

A bronze sword of ancient Greek origin, wielded as a sidearm to the dory spear.

This ancient bronze weapon features a curved, sickle-like blade sharpened on the outside edge.  Associated with the New Kingdom period of Ancient Egypt, it was designed mainly to hack through the light armor common to the region.

An ancient Chinese sword consisting of a curved blade and a guard with a cupped design.  Existing since the Shang dynasty, this one is made of bronze.  One of the four major weapons in folklore, alongside the jian sword, qiang spear, and gun staff.
An imitation of a sword made from bronze.  It is a capable weapon, but it cannot compare to actual swords.
A long, knife bladed bayonet that can be attached to the front of a rifle, converting it into a pike.  It is long enough to be used as a short sword when unmounted.

Long Japanese knives like this more-modern remake were the samurai's backup weapon, before the advent of the larger wakizashi.  It's still a deadly blade, even if it's smaller than its more famous relatives.
Long Japanese knives like this more-modern remake were the samurai's backup weapon, before the advent of the larger wakizashi.  This one doesn't feel well-balanced.
A dull, cheaply-made replica of a long Japanese knife, typically used as a samurai's backup weapon.
A comparatively-common Japanese short sword.  Smaller and lighter than a katana, but still effective in combat.

A weapon used for fencing, the most noble of all sports.  Unfortunately, a fencing foil is rather useless as a weapon due to its flexible shaft and dull tip.

What was once a mostly-harmless fencing foil has had its electrical plunger assembly removed and has been crudely sharpened to a point.  Though it still lacks a cutting edge, it is now somewhat more lethal, yet still familiar to the practiced fencer.

The modifications made to this fencing foil may not be sporting, but they might give you an edge in this final competition.  Extra effort has been made to insulate the grip and a high voltage stun gun has been attached to the guard, wired through the electronic scoring circuit to the tip.  Thrusting the sharpened tip into a foe and activating the momentary switch will deliver a painful electric shock.

A weapon used for fencing, the most noble of all sports.  While not designed for combat the pe is the heaviest and stiffest of the fencing weapons, and therefore perhaps still useful in your situation.

What was once a mostly-harmless fencing pe has had its electrical plunger assembly removed and has been crudely sharpened to a point.  Though it still lacks a cutting edge, it is now considerably more lethal, yet still familiar to the practiced fencer.

The modifications made to this fencing pe may not be sporting, but they might give you an edge in this final competition.  Extra effort has been made to insulate the grip and a high voltage stun gun has been attached to the guard, wired through the electronic scoring circuit to the tip.  Thrusting the sharpened tip into a foe and activating the momentary switch will deliver a painful electric shock.
A weapon used for fencing, the most noble of all sports.  Not designed for combat the saber at least bears an edge and so outperforms the foil, though still lacks the weight of the pe.

What was once a mostly-harmless fencing saber has had its rounded tip snapped off and has been crudely sharpened to a point.  Though it still lacks a cutting edge, it is now considerably more lethal, yet still familiar to the practiced fencer.

The modifications made to this fencing saber may not be sporting, but they might give you an edge in this final competition.  Extra effort has been made to insulate the grip and a high voltage stun gun has been attached to the guard, wired to the tip along the saber's groove.  Thrusting the sharpened tip into a foe and activating the momentary switch will deliver a painful electric shock.
A cane designed to conceal a blade.  This was a popular fashion accessory for the wealthy during the 18th and 19th centuries.
A sword with a thin blade designed to be hidden inside a hollow cane.
An Early Modern sword that saw use in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.  Called 'broad' to contrast with the slimmer rapiers.

An early modern sword that saw use in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.  Called 'broad' to contrast with the slimmer rapiers.

Made of hardened steel and with a molded grip that fits your hand perfectly, this weapon looks as good as any you might find in a museum.  The balance is perfect and the edge is as sharp as a razor.

An early modern sword that saw use in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.  Called 'broad' to contrast with the slimmer rapiers.

Made of tempered steel, this is a masterpiece.  The grip, the balance, the blade, all perfect.  This is the peak of the swordsmith's craft.
An Early Modern sword that saw use in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.  This sword appears to be made very poorly, but it should still stand up to a few swings.
A dull, cheaply-made replica of an Early Modern sword that saw use in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.  Called 'broad' to contrast with the slimmer rapiers.
A thin sword with an ornate hand guard.  It looks like the preferred weapon of gentlemen and swashbucklers.  Light and quick, it makes any battle a stylish battle.

Made with mild steel and lacking a proper grip, this is better than the sticks you swung around as a kid, but you know you can do better.

A master smith painstaikingly flaked its flowing blade from meteoric sea-green stone.  The hilt's cordage is speckled by gold flakes from the tummultous waters where the blade was whet, and the chosen tsuba depicts an all-devouring snake.
//: The stone blade isnt fully solid, and the idea is it gets AOE techniques and reach attacks from that (besides actually being quite long), should normally be inferior DPS wise vs a katana or nodachi.

description: A matched pair of traditional Shaolin butterfly swords.  They are about the same size as machetes, but have hand guards and wider blades.
//: basically 2x the weight, 1.3x the damage, 2.5x the resources of a single machete to cover the fact that it's two weapons, each with a hand guard

description: A broad saber known for its use by sailors and pirates, as its short blade is easy to handle in close quarters.

A single-edged two-handed sword of German design, with a long, curved blade.  It became popular across Europe due to its low cost while maintaining strong cutting power in comparison to the more sophisticated longsword.

description: An impractical exotic weapon comprised of a long pole of wood with curved blades on each end.
A chainsaw that has been lightened, tuned, and extensively modified to be easier to handle as a weapon.  Unfortunately, these modifications have rendered it much less effective as a woodcutting tool.

variables.success_message: With a snarl, the <npc_name> screams to life!
variables.failure_message: You yank the cord, but nothing happens.

description: This combat chainsaw is on, and is continuously draining gasoline.  Use it to turn it off.

An electric chainsaw that has been lightened, tuned, and extensively modified to be easier to handle as a weapon.  Unfortunately, these modifications have rendered it much less effective as a woodcutting tool.

variables.success_message: With a snarl, the <npc_name> screams to life!
variables.failure_message: You flip the switch, but nothing happens.

description: This electric combat chainsaw is on, and is continuously draining power.  Use it to turn it off.
A short, sharp double-edged dagger made to be gripped in the palm, with the blade protruding between the fingers.
Five pieces of rebar sharpened to cruel points and strapped to a brace fastened at the wrist and forearm on both arms.  The next bub better watch out.
Also called bagh nakha or iron paw, this small claw-like bladed weapon from India is designed to be concealed under and against the palm.
This is a vintage spike bayonet for the British Lee Enfield No. 4 rifle, featuring a distinct cruciform blade and socket-based mounting system.
//: VERY not intended for usage unmounted.

description: An essential tool within any 20th-century Japanese soldiers toolbox, the Type 30 is a massive, single-edged sword-style bayonet intended for use with Arisaka rifles and even light machineguns.  Possessing a J-shaped quillon guard for hooking an opponents weapon during combat, the bayonet, when dismounted, acts like a particularly sizable machete.

A curved sword used by the Raj of India in the 16th century, a talwar is usually impeccably decorated and able to take off a limb with a single swipe.

This one however is made of mild steel and lacks even a proper grip, you can definitely do better.

A curved sword used by the Raj of India in the 16th century, a talwar is usually impeccably decorated and able to take off a limb with a single swipe.

This one has a proper grip and is made of medium steel, but doesn't have the distinctive circular pommel yet.

A curved sword used by the Raj of India in the 16th century, a talwar is usually impeccably decorated and able to take off a limb with a single swipe.

This one has a proper grip and is made of high steel, you've even gotten the circular pommel right!

A curved sword used by the Raj of India in the 16th century, a talwar is usually impeccably decorated and able to take off a limb with a single swipe.

This one has a proper grip and is made of hardened steel and is otherwise a fine weapon.

A curved sword used by the Raj of India in the 16th century, a talwar is usually impeccably decorated and able to take off a limb with a single swipe.

This one has a proper grip and is made of tempered steel, and pre-apocalypse a Raj could have used it.

A Turkish sabre, the kilij is quite a bit heavier than most Middle Eastern sabres and has a distinctive wide tip called a yelman, which gives it vicious cutting power but means it requires a special scabbard.

This one has been made of mild steel, and doesn't even have a proper grip or truly sharp edge.
